# str_flatten

<center>
![](images/stringr_str_flatten.png){style="width:200px"}
</center>

The function `stringr::str_flatten()` allows you to create a single string from a character vector.

[Tidyverse reference page](https://stringr.tidyverse.org/reference/str_flatten.html)

## Flatten

By default `str_flatten()` will add no spaces/separators when flattening.

```{r}
#Create vector
vec <- c("A", "C", "G", "T")
#Flatten vector
vec |> stringr::str_flatten()
```

You can pipe the output for [`str_c()`](/stringr/str_c.qmd) to `str_flatten()`.

```{r}
#Create vectors
vec1 <- c("a", "b", "c")
vec2 <- c("x", "y", "z")
#Combine then flatten
stringr::str_c(vec1, vec2) |> stringr::str_flatten()
```

## Collapse and last

The individual vector elements can be separated in the out string with the `collapse=` option.

```{r}
#Create vector
vec <- c("A", "C", "G", "T")
#Flatten with , separator
stringr::str_flatten(vec, collapse = ",")
```

You can specify a final separator with `last =`.
Additionally, separators can contain as many characters as you would like.

```{r}
stringr::str_flatten(vec, collapse = ", ", last = ", and ")
```
